awd_titl_txt: Archaeological Investigation of the Eastern North Atlantic Trade and Globalizing Economic Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Paragraph 1: 
This award supports archaeological research on the development of trade networks in the North Atlantic and women's role in weaving cloth and participating in these trade networks for 1000 years. Past studies tell us that trade in the middle ages connected the North Atlantic islands to only one country. However, this scientist's earlier research showed that nearly 1,000 years ago the Vikings traded and sold cloth in London and other European markets. This means that 900 years ago, women in places as far away as the islands of the North Atlantic made cloth for markets in distant places. The reason this is important is because it suggests that women's work was key to developing commodity markets that were the ancestors of today's market. By understanding how early international trade began in the North Atlantic and expanded as far as the Volga river, the research will contribute knowledge about the emergence of today's more complicated trade systems, how trade affects women's labor, and how people make decisions about what to make and what to trade.

Paragraph 2: 
This scientific investigation will employ a mixed methodology to document and analyze textile collections from rural and urban, North Atlantic and European contexts.  AMS, dye and material analyses, strontium isotope analyses, and X-Ray Fluorescence will be employed to further characterize North Atlantic collections and compare them to previously collected data assemblages.    Strontium isotope analyses and pXRF data of archaeological samples and modern wool will be carried out in order to map isotopic signatures geographically and provide insight into the movements of textiles and the compounds used in their production across long distances, such as to North America, northern Europe and Eurasia.   Bringing together analyses ranging in scale from trans-continental trade to assessments of individual women's handiwork and to their products' elemental and isotopic signatures, this project has transformative potential to provide an engendered, interdisciplinary perspective on trade, women, and the emergence of early globalized economies in the North.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Archaeological Investigation of the Eastern North Atlantic Trade and Globalizing Economic Systems was a three-year project that was a natural outgrowth of two previous, successful, archaeological collections-based projects funded by NSF?s Arctic Social Sciences program. The project?s core goals were to examine the roles of women in the economies of the western and central North Atlantic (Iceland, Greenland, the Faroes, and northern Scotland) and document the trade in textiles from the North Atlantic to European harbors and centers. The approach suggested for monitoring the trade in cloth across the North Atlantic involved measuring bioavailable 87Sr/86Sr isotope ratios of woolen artefacts, using a method pioneered by Dr Karen M. Frei of the University of Copenhagen. Sheep ingest two isotopes of the element strontium (87Sr and 86Sr) in proportions that represent those isotopes? availability in the areas where they graze. By measuring those ratios in the animals? bones, teeth, and wool it may be possible to determine the areas where sheep grazed prior to the wool being shorn. A core idea in this grant was to assess this method?s potential for documenting trade in textiles between the North Atlantic and northern Europe during the Middle Ages and to document the involvement of the women who produced North Atlantic textiles in this trade. Countries where samples were to be collected included Norway, Denmark, the UK, Ireland, Russia, Iceland, Greenland, and the Faroe Islands. 

Unfortunately, the project was greatly impacted by the Covid -19 pandemic. Universities and businesses closed labs and governments, universities, museums and partner organizations instituted complete moratoria on international travel that, in some cases, extended until the spring of 2022. As a result, much of the project?s travel to collections had to be eliminated and the its scope was reduced to a more in-depth look at material from Norway, Iceland and Greenland, with analyses done in collaboration with students and faculty at Brown University?s Department of Geochemistry in the pre-pandemic period and with a commercial lab (Isobar Science, Miami FL) after Brown?s labs closed.

With the help of Norwegian colleagues who sent samples and carried out on-the-ground analyses we assessed the utility of the strontium isotope in a very targeted area of western Norway, the Sunnm?re region, comparing strontium ratios in textiles recovered from the archaeological site of Borgund (a medieval harbor town) to ratios in modern wool and vegetation samples from surrounding areas. The archaeological textiles and the modern wool and plant samples displayed extremely variable strontium ratios even though they all came from the same district, prompting us to consider the impact of other factors, including local geology and the impacts of sea spray, rain water, and atmospheric dust in inland and coastal settings. We were able to determine that no North Atlantic textiles had been imported to this site and that farms in nearby coastal lowlands most likely supplied the town of Borgund with woolens. However, it became clear that documenting local products and imports would require far more detailed isotope mapping than previous research had implied.

In Iceland, we also documented much higher levels of regional variability in bioavailable 87Sr/86Sr than previous researchers had assumed, showing that in Iceland, as well, this method would require much more detailed analysis at a regional level by much larger inter-disciplinary research teams than were possible within this project?s funding, especially during the pandemic.

In light of the problems identified with the strontium isotope method and with Covid?s travel restrictions, we explored another method for tracking the movement of cloth using portable X-Ray fluorescence (pXRF) analyses on 182 pieces of woolen cloth from 16 medieval Norse sites and 1 Ancestral Inuit site in Greenland. The results were surprisingly informative. Within both the Eastern and the Western Settlements, we were able to differentiate textiles from individual farms based on the ratios of 4-6 key elements, rubidium, strontium, uranium, and lead. We compared these results on wool to soils and vegetation from the same sites to ensure that our readings were not simply reflecting the soil in which the textiles were buried. They were not and the information we gained produced new insights on livestock management, community organization, and the movement of cloth within local communities and across Greenland. We concluded that, for this region, pXRF produced more manageable, tangible, cost-effective, and non-destructive results than strontium isotope analyses.

A core conclusion of this project is that using strontium isotope analyses to track the movement of cloth across a region as vast and geologically diverse as the North Atlantic would require multidisciplinary teams to address complex geological settings at local and regional levels, as well as the impacts of atmospheric and other factors on strontium isotope ratios. Strontium isotope analyses also require laboratories beyond the means of most researchers and the destruction of archaeological samples. pXRF may provide more manageable opportunities with significant results.
